results.title: As a matter of fact: a film about abortion
results.creator_credit: Women's Health Resources Foundation, Womens Film Fund, Creative Development Branch of Australian Film Commission, Susan Lambert and Robyn Dryen
results.brief_description: A documentary about a feminist run abortion clinic. Counselling is shown to be an important part of the procedure, which is carried out using local anaesthetic and the vacuum aspiration method. We follow one woman through the termination of her pregnancy, and other women tell why they chose to have an abortion. The film ends with an animated section on the struggle for free, legalised abortion in Australia and information on what to do and where to go if you are pregnant.
results.title_for_label: As a matter of fact: a film about abortion

results.title: In search of a landscape
results.creator_credit: Hannah Dunne and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: The pre-performance preparations by Hannah Dunne and her dance troupe as they practice for their performance of “In search of a landscape”. Hannah describes to the viewer how she arrived at the name for this particular piece. NB: This video was donated by the performer and has a grainy quality. You do not need to adjust your machine.

results.title: Artists in cyberculture
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Cohen, Frances McGivern and Cracked Metal Productions
results.brief_description: Artists record their work at the Third International Symposium on Electronic Art, Sydney, 1992. Through a series of interviews, performance, electronic theatre, this video looks at ways in which artists challenge the emerging technological realm known as “cyberculture”. It also examines issues such as gender, the body, the homogenisation of culture and the social and environmental implications of new technologies. Three of the artists interviewed are Char Davies, Stelarc and Myron Kreuger.

results.title: Jack Lindsay
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Jack Lindsay speaks about his relationship with his father, Norman Lindsay, and their shared interest in the classical world. He recalls the cultural life of Sydney in the 1920s and his memories of writers Kenneth Slessor, Christopher Brennan and Henry Lawson. Lindsay left Australia in 1926 and remained in England for the rest of his life. A poet, novelist, translator, historian, critic and biographer, Lindsay discusses the influence of political thought on his writing and his involvement in the anti-Facist Union of Poets and the Authors’ World Peace Appeal. He remembers his friendships with fellow poets Dylan Thomas, Edith Sitwell, Aragon, Tristan Tzara and Paul Eluard.

results.title: Manning Clark
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Author and historian Manning Clark recalls the events of his early childhood, the attitudes of his family and how they influenced his writing. He speaks at length about the process of researching and writing his multi- volume History of Australia and how his outlook changed over the years of writing it. He speaks candidly about the public reaction to his work and addresses his critics. Interviewed by James Murdoch during Australia’s bicentennial year, 1988, Clark reflects on the past and expresses his hopes for the future of Australian society.

results.title: Joan Lindsay
results.creator_credit: Ian McKay, Australia Council and AAV Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
In this interview with John Taylor, Joan Lindsay speaks about her experiences as an art student at the National Gallery School in Melbourne and her decision to become a writer. She talks about her marriage to the painter Daryl Lindsay. Lindsay describes the process of writing her novel, “Picnic at Hanging Rock”, and her preoccupation with time as a theme. Related to both the Boyd and Lindsay families, she gives a unique insight into the personalities of some of Australia’s leading artists.

results.title: Robert D. Fitzgerald
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Acclaimed poet Robert D. Fitzgerald describes himself as a “professional surveyor and an amateur poet”. He recalls his experiences working for the Native Lands Commission in the remote interior regions of Fiji which inspired his poem “Between two tides”. Fitzgerald remembers his friendship with fellow writers Kenneth Slessor, Jack and Phillip Lindsay, Douglas Stewart and Dame Mary Gilmore. During the Vietnam war, Fitzgerald was active in the anti-war movement. He discusses the reasons for his involvement and recalls the events surrounding the Arts Vietnam protest.

results.title: Tommy
results.brief_description: Using interviews with and about Tommy Woodcock, this program tells the story of one of Australia’s most renowned racehorse trainers. In particular it concentrates on his work with Phar Lap and Reckless.

results.title: Russell Drysdale
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Painters, the sculptors: archival art series”.
Russell Drysdale tells of his early years, of the changes in the Australian art scene since World War II; his fascination with the “great quietness” of the landscape and the methods he employs in his painting.

results.title: Judah Waten
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Elisabeth Knight and Darrelyn Gunzburg
results.brief_description: In an interview conducted at his home in Victoria in December 1982, Judah Waten discusses his writing, his life, his Jewish background, political views and Russian, Yiddish and Australian influences on his writing, including the experiences of migrants. This is interspersed with brief remarks by a number of his friends, including Manning Clark, Justice Judith Cohen and Alan Marshall.
